docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 18 -Sao Paulo police investigating Axis fifth column activities have rounded up several Japanese, including Misutaka Taoki, alias Misutaka Aoko, who calls himself "Count."

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Uruguayan Government informed the United States in a note from its Foreign Minister, Dr. Alberto Guani, dated yesterday and made public today by the State Department, that as soon as all the facts were assembled it would...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Uruguayan Government informed the United States in a note from its Foreign Minister, Dr. Alberto Guani, dated yesterday and made public today by the State Department, that as soon as all the facts were assembled it would present the case of the sinking of the Uruguyan merchant ship Montevideo by an Axis submarine to the Pan American Union for "appropriate action."

docs.snippet: All aliens, including enemy aliens, are to be reclassified by their draft boards forthwith, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday. Colonel McDermott said that he had received instructions from...
docs.lead_paragraph: All aliens, including enemy aliens, are to be reclassified by their draft boards forthwith, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday. Colonel McDermott said that he had received instructions from Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, National Director of Selective Service, for this action.

headline.main: ALIENS IN DRAFT FACE WAR SERVICE; All of Them, Including Enemy Subjects to Be Reclassified, McDermott Says NEUTRALS MAY ESCAPE But if They Seek Exemption They Will Be Barred From Citizenship Forever

docs.snippet: THE accelerated pace of the war in the Pacific has given this book a plausibility that not even its author could have dreamed of at the time of writing it only a few months ago. In a normal world these hastily concocted pages would "sound like a...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE accelerated pace of the war in the Pacific has given this book a plausibility that not even its author could have dreamed of at the time of writing it only a few months ago. In a normal world these hastily concocted pages would "sound like a cheap spy story," in the very words used by the author.
